children.value: Utilizing intake to open a HEALPix data catalog
package to perform HEALPix operations to look at basic statistics
Plotting HEALPix data via easy.gems functionality
Getting started with hierarchical HEALPix data - easy.gems Documentation
If you think that you first need to learn about Intake, Pythia’s
is a great resource to do so.
Let us use the online data catalog from the WCRP’s Digital Earths Global Hackathon 2025’s
and read the output of the
, which is stored in the HEALPix format:

import intake

# Hackathon data catalogs
cat_url = "https://digital-earths-global-hackathon.github.io/catalog/catalog.yaml"
cat = intake.open_catalog(cat_url).online
model_run = cat.icon_ngc4008
We highly recommend checking out the
easy.gems documentation on HEALPix data catalogs
parametrization of the model runs in the catalogs. In short, each model run has an independent
easy.gems documentation on HEALPix data catalogs
, and “PT30M” in this figure should be “PT15M”, 15 minutes, for the hackathon data we are using here)
So, the coarsest dataset in this model run would be as follows (Even if we called it without specifying any parameters, i.e.
, the result would be same as the
below since this model run defaults to the coarsest settings):

children.label: HEALPix basic stats with thehealpix package

children.value: Let us look at the global and Boulder, CO, USA temperature averages for a 3-year time-slice of the whole dataset.
For this, we will first need to define a few HEALPix helper functions to get the
values from the dataset, then find the HEALPix pixel that Boulder coords fall in, and finally plot those temporal averages using

import healpix as hp
import matplotlib.pylab as plt

%%time
boulder_lon = -105.2747
boulder_lat = 40.0190

boulder_pixel = hp.ang2pix(
    get_nside(ds_fine), boulder_lon, boulder_lat, lonlat=True, nest=get_nest(ds_fine)
)

data.name: stdout
data.text:
CPU times: user 227 μs, sys: 66 μs, total: 293 μs
Wall time: 297 μs

data.name: stdout
data.text:
CPU times: user 344 ms, sys: 178 ms, total: 523 ms
Wall time: 2.14 s

children.value: In this part, we will look at the

import easygems.healpix as eghp

import cartopy.crs as ccrs
import cartopy.feature as cf
import cmocean
code, but have a look at how
is called. The following code will plot global temperature (at the first timestep for simplicity)

projection = ccrs.Robinson(central_longitude=-135.5808361)

fig, ax = plt.subplots(
    figsize=(8, 4), subplot_kw={"projection": projection}, constrained_layout=True
)

ax.set_global()

eghp.healpix_show(ds_fine.tas.isel(time=0), ax=ax, cmap=cmocean.cm.thermal)

ax.add_feature(cf.COASTLINE, linewidth=0.8)
ax.add_feature(cf.BORDERS, linewidth=0.4)
If plotting a region of interest is desired, it is also possible through setting extents of the
Let us look into USA map using the Boulder, CO, USA coords we had used before for simplicity:

projection = ccrs.Robinson(central_longitude=boulder_lon)

fig, ax = plt.subplots(
    figsize=(8, 4), subplot_kw={"projection": projection}, constrained_layout=True
)
ax.set_extent([boulder_lon-20, boulder_lon+40, boulder_lat-20, boulder_lat+10], crs=ccrs.PlateCarree())

eghp.healpix_show(ds_fine.tas.isel(time=0), ax=ax, cmap=cmocean.cm.thermal)

ax.add_feature(cf.COASTLINE, linewidth=0.8)
ax.add_feature(cf.BORDERS, linewidth=0.4)
These are only a sampling of HEALPix and easy.gems capabilities; if you are interested in learning more, be sure to check out the usage examples at the
will provide an UXarray workflow that loads in and analyzes & visualizes HEALPix data.
